items.synopsis: Scratch the surface of the Voice referendum results, and a more complicated picture emerges.

title.children: What the places with the highest and lowest Yes vote can tell us about the Voice

items.synopsis: The New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council is holding "a week of silence" to mourn the outcome of the referendum, as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags are lowered to half-mast. Follow live.

title.children: AEC rejects suggestions of interference at remote polls, as Indigenous leaders start 'week of silence'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Lauren Roberts Federal Labor Lingiari MP Marion Scrymgour says there are some "good results" for the Yes camp in the numbers pouring in from remote Northern Territory polling stations. "If you look at the Northern Territory results – particularly in Lingiari – there are some good results and we shouldn't lose sight of that," she said. "Overwhelmingly, Aboriginal people in remote communities voted Yes. "They wanted change, they wanted recognition, they want government to listen to what's happening on the ground in those communities." The NT, which has the nation's highest rate of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander residents, voted No to the Voice. Ms Scrymgour said there was "probably an element of racism" influencing the results. "There was a lot of bullying and other misinformation that was peddled out," she said. Ms Scrymgour said there was "no such thing" as a "progressive No". "I don't think you can have a treaty in this country without recognition at the highest level and I think that's what people all lost in this, there's no such thing as a progressive No in this country," she said. "Either you're a No or a Yes and people need to stop hiding between this." You can read more about how the NT voted here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NT remote polls 'overwhelmingly' back Yes vote

featuredLink.title: The NT voted No to the Voice, but results show remote communities backed Yes

children.content: Reporting by Lauren Roberts
Federal Labor Lingiari MP Marion Scrymgour says there are some "good results" for the Yes camp in the numbers pouring in from remote Northern Territory polling stations.
"If you look at the Northern Territory results – particularly in Lingiari – there are some good results and we shouldn't lose sight of that," she said.
"Overwhelmingly, Aboriginal people in remote communities voted Yes.
"They wanted change, they wanted recognition, they want government to listen to what's happening on the ground in those communities."
The NT, which has the nation's highest rate of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander residents, voted No to the Voice.
Ms Scrymgour said there was "probably an element of racism" influencing the results.
"There was a lot of bullying and other misinformation that was peddled out," she said.
Ms Scrymgour said there was "no such thing" as a "progressive No".

"I don't think you can have a treaty in this country without recognition at the highest level and I think that's what people all lost in this, there's no such thing as a progressive No in this country," she said.
"Either you're a No or a Yes and people need to stop hiding between this."
You can read more about how the NT voted here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price questioned the impartiality of the delivery of remote polling across Australia last night. She also suggested people handing out how-to-vote cards “overpower vulnerable Aboriginal communities”, in response to the fact many Indigenous communities voted Yes. “One thing we do know is the way in which Indigenous people in remote communities are exploited for the purpose of somebody else’s agenda,” she says. “I think we probably need to look at the way the AEC, the Northern Territory Electoral commission, conduct themselves when it comes to remote polling at elections, at referendums. “I think we should take away those who come in with their how-to-votes, unions that come in and overpower vulnerable Aboriginal communities. “There is a lot that goes on in remote communities that the rest of Australia doesn’t get to see. If we had cameras in those remote communities, at those polling booths, Australia would see what goes on in within those communities. There’s a lot of manipulation.” In a statement to the ABC, the AEC says: “The ability to campaign at any polling place, including in remote communities, was of course the same for everyone.” “We were pleased to have delivered the largest remote voting offering ever with an approximate 25% increase in the number of votes taken in remote communities.’ “This was off the back of record rate of enrolment overall, as well as for Indigenous Australians. " The AEC told the ABC Senator Price wasn’t referring to the AEC’s actions but rather potentially the process of voting in remote communities, the campaigning activities and electoral laws.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AEC responds after Jacinta Nampijinpa Price questions conduct at polls

children.content: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price questioned the impartiality of the delivery of remote polling across Australia last night.
She also suggested people handing out how-to-vote cards “overpower vulnerable Aboriginal communities”, in response to the fact many Indigenous communities voted Yes.
“One thing we do know is the way in which Indigenous people in remote communities are exploited for the purpose of somebody else’s agenda,” she says.
“I think we probably need to look at the way the AEC, the Northern Territory Electoral commission, conduct themselves when it comes to remote polling at elections, at referendums.
“I think we should take away those who come in with their how-to-votes, unions that come in and overpower vulnerable Aboriginal communities.

“There is a lot that goes on in remote communities that the rest of Australia doesn’t get to see. If we had cameras in those remote communities, at those polling booths, Australia would see what goes on in within those communities. There’s a lot of manipulation.”
In a statement to the ABC, the AEC says: “The ability to campaign at any polling place, including in remote communities, was of course the same for everyone.”
“We were pleased to have delivered the largest remote voting offering ever with an approximate 25% increase in the number of votes taken in remote communities.’
“This was off the back of record rate of enrolment overall, as well as for Indigenous Australians. "
The AEC told the ABC Senator Price wasn’t referring to the AEC’s actions but rather potentially the process of voting in remote communities, the campaigning activities and electoral laws.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Stacey Pestrin and Imogen Hayne South Australian One Nation MP Sarah Game will move to repeal the state's Voice to Parliament, in the wake of the defeated referendum. South Australia became the first jurisdiction in the country to legislate a state-based First Nations Voice to Parliament in March and elections are due to be held next March. Ms Game, a state Upper House MP, plans to give notice on her First Nations Voice Repeal Bill on Tuesday. She said she was concerned the state Voice lacked "genuine consultation" with South Australians and would be an "enormous arm of government so heavy it will lift no-one". But Premier Peter Malinauskas said the Voice had been legislated "after probably one of the most exhaustive pieces of community consultation that I've borne witness to". South Australia's Aboriginal Affairs Minister, Kyam Maher, said Ms Game's planned repeal bill was "disappointing" but he had spoken to his colleagues in the legislative council and they were "committed and absolutely resolved to our South Australian First Nations Voice". "There actually is zero prospect of this being repealed," he said. Mr Maher said elections will go ahead for the South Australian Voice early next year. "I think many people, even the most vocal opponents during this referendum, have talked about the importance of local voices and that's exactly what we're doing in South Australia," he said. "There will be a series of local voices elected on March 16 next year by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander South Australians, and representatives from those local voices will form the state's First Nations voice. Mr Malinauskas said the state's legislated Voice was "very different in nature" to a constitutional change, and would be a "non-binding advisory committee" similar to other existing advisory bodies. "No different to what we have with the South Australian multicultural affairs commission or the construction industry skills commission. It'll be similar in nature to that," he said. South Australia's commissioner for First Nations Voice, Dale Agius, said a third round of community consultations would take place in a couple of weeks, explaining how to nominate and vote for the state-based Voice. He said while the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people he had spoken to were "a little bit upset and disappointed" with yesterday's outcome, "the excitement for the state-based process still continues". SA Opposition leader David Speirs did not comment on Ms Game’s bill, but said the Liberals would be open to amending legislation related to the state’s Voice “should it be deemed not to be working”. “That might include, should we conclude that South Australians don’t want this state voice. They clearly don’t want a federal voice.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: South Australian MP plans to move to repeal state Voice

children.content: Reporting by Stacey Pestrin and Imogen Hayne
South Australian One Nation MP Sarah Game will move to repeal the state's Voice to Parliament, in the wake of the defeated referendum.
South Australia became the first jurisdiction in the country to legislate a state-based First Nations Voice to Parliament in March and elections are due to be held next March.
Ms Game, a state Upper House MP, plans to give notice on her First Nations Voice Repeal Bill on Tuesday.
She said she was concerned the state Voice lacked "genuine consultation" with South Australians and would be an "enormous arm of government so heavy it will lift no-one".
But Premier Peter Malinauskas said the Voice had been legislated "after probably one of the most exhaustive pieces of community consultation that I've borne witness to".

South Australia's Aboriginal Affairs Minister, Kyam Maher, said Ms Game's planned repeal bill was "disappointing" but he had spoken to his colleagues in the legislative council and they were "committed and absolutely resolved to our South Australian First Nations Voice".

props.alt: Two men stand wearing Aborignal flag t-shirts.

children.content: Kyam Maher and Dale Agius.
(Supplied: Ethan Rix)
"There actually is zero prospect of this being repealed," he said.
Mr Maher said elections will go ahead for the South Australian Voice early next year.
"I think many people, even the most vocal opponents during this referendum, have talked about the importance of local voices and that's exactly what we're doing in South Australia," he said.

"There will be a series of local voices elected on March 16 next year by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander South Australians, and representatives from those local voices will form the state's First Nations voice.
Mr Malinauskas said the state's legislated Voice was "very different in nature" to a constitutional change, and would be a "non-binding advisory committee" similar to other existing advisory bodies.
"No different to what we have with the South Australian multicultural affairs commission or the construction industry skills commission. It'll be similar in nature to that," he said.

South Australia's commissioner for First Nations Voice, Dale Agius, said a third round of community consultations would take place in a couple of weeks, explaining how to nominate and vote for the state-based Voice.

He said while the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people he had spoken to were "a little bit upset and disappointed" with yesterday's outcome, "the excitement for the state-based process still continues".
SA Opposition leader David Speirs did not comment on Ms Game’s bill, but said the Liberals would be open to amending legislation related to the state’s Voice “should it be deemed not to be working”.
“That might include, should we conclude that South Australians don’t want this state voice. They clearly don’t want a federal voice.”

items.synopsis: The foreign minister says multiple repatriation flights for Australians stuck in Israel and the West Bank may be able take off from Tel Aviv today, as Israel prepares to go into Gaza. Follow live.

title.children: Repatriation flights from Israel 'may be able to take off' today, Penny Wong says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says multiple repatriation flights for Australians stuck in Israel and the West Bank may be able to take-off from Tel Aviv today. She wrote on social media the situation in the area continues to change rapidly, and the flights are subject to the deteriorating security environment in the region. Yesterday, the Department of Foreign Affairs cancelled scheduled flights due to depart this weekend due to security concerns.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Government planning multiple repatriation flights from Tel Aviv today

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says multiple repatriation flights for Australians stuck in Israel and the West Bank may be able to take-off from Tel Aviv today.
She wrote on social media the situation in the area continues to change rapidly, and the flights are subject to the deteriorating security environment in the region.
Yesterday, the Department of Foreign Affairs cancelled scheduled flights due to depart this weekend due to security concerns.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Pentagon has ordered a second aircraft carrier strike group to the eastern Mediterranean, near Israel. The USS Dwight D Eisenhower Carrier Strike Group (CSG) will depart from Norfolk in Virginia and includes a  guided-missile cruiser, three guided-missile destroyers, nine aircraft squadrons, and personnel. Secretary of Defense Lloyd J Austin said the shipment of more warships and aircraft was an effort to deter "hostile actions against Israel". The primary mission appears to be preventing Hezbollah, Iran or others from taking advantage of the situation in Israel and Gaza. "The increases to US force Posture signal the United States' ironclad commitment to Israel’s security and our resolve to deter any state or non-state actor seeking to escalate this war," Austin said in a statement. He is expected to arrive in Israel on Friday and meet with leaders to discuss what else the US can provide to the country.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pentagon says US is sending a second aircraft carrier to the region

children.content: The Pentagon has ordered a second aircraft carrier strike group to the eastern Mediterranean, near Israel.

The USS Dwight D Eisenhower Carrier Strike Group (CSG) will depart from Norfolk in Virginia and includes a  guided-missile cruiser, three guided-missile destroyers, nine aircraft squadrons, and personnel.
Secretary of Defense Lloyd J Austin said the shipment of more warships and aircraft was an effort to deter "hostile actions against Israel".
The primary mission appears to be preventing Hezbollah, Iran or others from taking advantage of the situation in Israel and Gaza.

"The increases to US force Posture signal the United States' ironclad commitment to Israel’s security and our resolve to deter any state or non-state actor seeking to escalate this war," Austin said in a statement.
He is expected to arrive in Israel on Friday and meet with leaders to discuss what else the US can provide to the country.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Syrian defence ministry says Israel has launched an air strike against the international airport in Aleppo, which has put it out of service. This is the statement it gave to Reuters: "The Israeli enemy carried out an air attack from the direction of the Mediterranean Sea, west of Latakia, targeting Aleppo International Airport, which led to material damage to the airport and it being out of service," the ministry said. This is not the first time the airport has been hit. Two days ago, Syria's state media reported Israeli forces had launched "simultaneous" missile strikes on two main airports in Aleppo and Damascus. The attack damaged both runways and put both hubs out of service. The strikes on the airports are intended to disrupt Iranian supply lines to Syria, a source told Reuters. The Israeli military has not commented on the strikes, but earlier said that two rockets had been launched from Syria toward Israeli territory that "fell in an open area". "No interceptors were activated according to protocol," the IDF said of that incident.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Syria says Israeli airstrikes have hit Aleppo international airport again

children.content: The Syrian defence ministry says Israel has launched an air strike against the international airport in Aleppo, which has put it out of service.
This is the statement it gave to Reuters:

"The Israeli enemy carried out an air attack from the direction of the Mediterranean Sea, west of Latakia, targeting Aleppo International Airport, which led to material damage to the airport and it being out of service," the ministry said.
This is not the first time the airport has been hit. Two days ago, Syria's state media reported Israeli forces had launched "simultaneous" missile strikes on two main airports in Aleppo and Damascus.
The attack damaged both runways and put both hubs out of service.
The strikes on the airports are intended to disrupt Iranian supply lines to Syria, a source told Reuters.
The Israeli military has not commented on the strikes, but earlier said that two rockets had been launched from Syria toward Israeli territory that "fell in an open area".
"No interceptors were activated according to protocol," the IDF said of that incident.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I had this as 118-108 in favour of Sam Goodman. 118-107 and 120-105 twice go the judges. All in favour of Goodman! He remains undefeated. "He tested my body out and a couple of other bits out," Goodman says. Flores is still annoyed at the low blows, but the footage was conclusive in that the Mexican did hit him very low.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sam Goodman remains undefeated

children.content: (No Limit Boxing: Zain Mohammed)
I had this as 118-108 in favour of Sam Goodman.
118-107 and 120-105 twice go the judges.
All in favour of Goodman!
He remains undefeated.
"He tested my body out and a couple of other bits out," Goodman says.
Flores is still annoyed at the low blows, but the footage was conclusive in that the Mexican did hit him very low.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Time for the co-main event of the night, 12 rounds between Sam Goodman (15-0) and Mexican challenger Miguel Flores (25-4-1). Goodman is the mandatory challenger for Naoya Inoue's WBO junior featherweight title and is ranked 1 by the IBF as well, with Marlon Tapales currently holding that belt at the 122lb (55.33kg) limit. This contest is a bit of an odd one for me, taking place at a catch weight of 125lb, I'm just not sure what Goodman has to gain by taking on a dangerous Mexican (in a boxing ring, there is no other type of Mexican, by the way). Both men made the weight, 56.56kg for Goodman and 56.6kg for Flores. El Michoacano is a former world title challenger, taking on four-weight world champion Léo Santa Cruz for the WBA (Super) super featherweight title, which he lost by unanimous decision.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sam Goodman vs Miguel Flores

children.content: (No Limit Boxing: Zain Mohammed)
Time for the co-main event of the night, 12 rounds between
Sam Goodman
(15-0) and Mexican challenger
Miguel Flores
Goodman is the mandatory challenger for
Naoya Inoue's WBO junior featherweight title and is ranked 1 by the IBF as well, with
Marlon Tapales currently holding that belt at the 122lb (55.33kg) limit.

This contest is a bit of an odd one for me, taking place at a catch weight of 125lb, I'm just not sure what Goodman has to gain by taking on a dangerous Mexican (in a boxing ring, there is no other type of Mexican, by the way).
Both men made the weight, 56.56kg for Goodman and 56.6kg for Flores.
El Michoacano is a former world title challenger, taking on four-weight world champion
Léo Santa Cruz for the
WBA (Super) super featherweight title, which he lost by unanimous decision.
